revision.comment: removed spam link to unreliable source
revision.text:
{{Other people|Neil Patel|Neil Patel (disambiguation){{!}}Neil Patel}} {{Infobox person | image = NeilPatel.jpg | image_size = 200px | name = Neil Patel | ethnicity = [[Indian people|Indian]] | birth_date = April 24, 1985 | birth_place = [[London, England]] | known_for = KISSmetrics, Crazy Egg | nationality = | net_worth = }} '''Neil Patel''' is a Seattle based [[entrepreneur]], [[angel investor]], and [[analytics|analytics expert]].<ref name=forbes>{{cite web|last=Rogers|first=Bruce|title=Neil Patel's KISSMETRICS Brings Big Data to Small Companies to Optimize the Customer Experience|url=http://www.forbes.com/sites/brucerogers/2013/01/09/neil-patels-kissmetrics-brings-big-data-to-small-companies-to-optimize-the-customer-experience/|publisher=Forbes|date=January 9, 2013}}</ref><ref name=cnn>{{cite web|last=Macguire|first=Eoghan|title=Dotcom millionaire who lives in a hotel|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/05/24/business/millionaire-lives-hotel/index.html|publisher=CNN|date=May 24, 2012}}</ref> He is best known for his work in [[digital marketing]] and as the cofounder of the [[analytics]] companies KISSmetrics and Crazy Egg.<ref name=mash>{{cite web|last=Gerber|first=Scott|title=Announcing a Live Chat With Crazy Egg and KISSmetrics Founder Neil Patel|url=http://mashable.com/2012/11/07/live-chat-crazy-egg-kissmetrics-2/|publisher=Mashable|date=November 7, 2012}}</ref><ref name=mo>{{cite web|last=Sullivan|first=Mike|title=At 21, Neil Patel was named a top 100 blogger by Technorati and one of the top influencers on the web according to the Wall Street Journal.|url=http://www.mo.com/entrepreneur-interview-neil-patel-founder-crazy-egg-kiss-metrics/|publisher=m.o.|date=August 2, 2012}}</ref>
==Career== Patel launched his first online venture, a job board named Advice Monkey, while in high school.<ref name=found>{{cite web|last=Gould|first=Jay|title=How Neil Patel Became a Successful Serial Internet Entrepreneur|url=http://foundville.com/2011/12/19/neil-patel-interview/|publisher=Foundville|date=December 19, 2011}}</ref> After the marketing companies Patel hired for the project failed to gain the company any traction, he decided to learn how to drive traffic to his site, thus launching his career in online marketing.<ref name=things>{{cite web|last=Patel|first=Neil|title=17 things I wish I’d known when starting my first business|url=http://www.geekwire.com/2011/17-starting-business/|publisher=GeekWire|date=October 19, 2011}}</ref> By 2009, Patel had implemented his marketing and search engine optimization tactics on 30 of the top 100 [[Technorati]] blogs and was named one of the top influencers on the web by ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''.<ref name=mash/><ref name=keynote>{{cite web|last=Baker|first=Loren|title=Neil Patel to Keynote SEO Day at IM Spring Break|url=http://www.searchenginejournal.com/neil-patel-to-keynote-seo-day-at-im-spring-break/8830/|publisher=Search Engine Journal|date=February 24, 2009}}</ref>
In 2006, Patel started his first blog, ProNet Advertising.<ref name=pcworld>{{cite web|last=Gohring|first=Nancy|title=Search optimizers turn to social sites|url=http://www.pcworld.idg.com.au/article/185467/search_optimizers_turn_social_sites/|publisher=PC World|date=June 6, 2007}}</ref><ref name=dbt>{{cite web|last=Scocco|first=Daniel|title=Interview with the Pronet Advertising Guys|url=http://www.dailyblogtips.com/interview-with-the-pronet-advertising-guys/|publisher=Daily Blog Tips|date=January 27, 2007}}</ref> The next year, the blog was named Search Engine Journal's "Best Social Media Blog" and first ranked in [[Technorati|Technorati's Top 100]].<ref name=mo/><ref name=pronet>{{cite web|last=Baker|first=Loren|title=Pronet Advertising : Best Social Media Optimization Blog|url=http://www.searchenginejournal.com/pronet-advertising-best-social-media-optimization-blog/4214/|publisher=Search Engine Journal|date=January 5, 2007 }}</ref><ref name=blogtalk>{{cite web|last=Hung|first=Tony|title=Neil Patel on ProNet Advertising, social media and more|url=http://www.bloggertalks.com/2007/02/neil-patel-on-pronet-advertising-social-media-and-more/|publisher=Blogger Talks|date=February 6, 2007 }}</ref> Patel's current blog, Quick Sprout, produces annual revenues in excess of $1 million and has been featured in news outlets including [[Inc. Magazine]], [[Forbes]], [[Gigaom]], and [[Business Insider]].<ref name=writerviews>{{cite web|last=Alexis|first=Michael|title=How Neil Patel Makes Millions From Quicksprout|url=http://www.writerviews.com/neil-patel-interview-quicksprout/|publisher=Writer Views|date=January 10, 2012}}</ref><ref name=inc>{{cite web|last=Wehrum|first=Kasey|title=The Case Against Apple and 53 Tips to Boost Your Biz|url=http://www.inc.com/staff-blog/2009/08/the_case_agains.html|publisher=Inc.|date=August 10, 2009}}</ref><ref name=info>{{cite web|last=McCue|first=TJ|title=Why Infographics Rule|url=http://www.forbes.com/sites/tjmccue/2013/01/08/what-is-an-infographic-and-ways-to-make-it-go-viral/|publisher=Forbes|date=January 8, 2013}}</ref><ref name=gigaom>{{cite web|last=Babauta|first=Leo|title=The 3 Laws of Online Personal Branding|url=http://gigaom.com/2007/07/26/the-3-laws-of-online-personal-branding-and-why-your-efforts-might-be-wasted/|publisher=Gigaom|date=July 26, 2007}}</ref><ref name=bitrends>{{cite web|last=Small Business Trends|title=Creating Content for Small Business|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/creating-content-for-small-business-2012-2|publisher=Business Insider|date=February 27, 2012}}</ref>
Patel is also a contributor to publications including [[Entrepreneur Magazine]], [[TechCrunch]], [[Mashable]], [[Business Insider]], [[SEOmoz]], and Geekwire.<ref name=ent>{{cite web|title=Author Profile: Neil Patel|url=http://www.entrepreneur.com/author/1780|publisher=Entrepreneur}}</ref><ref name=tc>{{cite web|last=Patel|first=Neil|title=How To Grow Your Blog Through Customer Development|url=http://techcrunch.com/2009/05/02/how-to-grow-your-blog-through-customer-development/|publisher=TechCrunch|date=May 2, 2009}}</ref><ref name=bi>{{cite web|title=Author Profile: Neil Patel|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/author/neil-patel|publisher=Business Insider}}</ref><ref name=seomoz>{{cite web|title=Member Profile: Neil Patel|url=http://www.seomoz.org/users/profile/361137|publisher=SEOmoz}}</ref><ref name=geek>{{cite web|title=Author Profile: Neil Patel|url=http://www.geekwire.com/author/neil-patel/|publisher=GeekWire}}</ref>
===Advantage Consulting Services (ACS)=== In 2002 Patel co-founded ACS, an online [[search engine optimization]] (SEO) and marketing company, with business partner [[Hiten Shah]].<ref name=newdirection>{{cite web|last=Tiffany|first=Laura|title=A New Direction|url=http://www.entrepreneur.com/article/183044|publisher=Entrepreneur|date=September 1, 2007}}</ref> By 2007, the company was doing more than $2.5 million a year in sales.<ref name=newdirection/> Patel and ACS would continue on to consult a variety of Fortune 500 companies including [[Hewlett Packard]], [[Samsung]], [[Amazon.com|Amazon]], [[Microsoft]], [[AOL]], [[Walmart]], [[General Motors]], and [[Viacom]].<ref name=mo/><ref name=blogtalk/><ref name=ss>{{cite web|last=Kumar Saha|first=Mousumi|title=Success Story of Neil Patel, Co-founder of two Successful Startups Crazy Egg and KISSmetrics|publisher=Success Stories|date=February 17, 2012}}</ref><ref name=yec>{{cite web|title=Author Bio: Neil Patel|url=http://youngentrepreneurcouncil.com/author/neilp/|publisher=Young Entrepreneur Council}}</ref>
===Crazy Egg=== In 2006, Patel and Shah founded Crazy Egg, a company which helps individuals and businesses determine what visitors are doing when they visit their site.<ref name=cegg>{{cite web|last=Cubrilovic|first=Nik|title=See What Your Website Visitors Are Doing With Crazy Egg|url=http://techcrunch.com/2006/03/13/see-what-your-website-visitors-are-doing-with-crazy-egg/|publisher=TechCrunch|date=March 13, 2006}}</ref> The information is displayed in "heatmaps", showing where visitors clicked while on the site, a more visual method than the traditional analytics programs available at the time.<ref name=crazy>{{cite web|last=Townes|first=Frederick|title=Crazy Egg is Crazy Delicious!|url=http://mashable.com/2006/03/10/crazy-egg-is-crazy-delicious/|publisher=Mashable|date=March 10, 2006}}</ref> Shortly after launch, Patel reportedly had a $5 million offer to sell Crazy Egg, yet declined, saying he felt the company would sell for at least $10 million.<ref name=mixergy>{{cite web|last=Warner|first=Andrew|title=CrazyEgg: The Slow-Build Bootstrap – with Neil Patel|url=http://mixergy.com/crazyegg-neil-patel-interview/|publisher=Mixergy|date=September 28, 2010}}</ref>
===KISSmetrics=== In 2008 Patel co-founded KISSmetrics, a customer analytics platform designed for small and mid-sized companies, again with business partner Hiten Shah.<ref name=forbes/><ref name=vb>{{cite web|last=Koetsier|first=John|title=Neil Patel’s 10 tips on using metrics to make money|url=http://venturebeat.com/2012/08/23/neil-patel-likes-to-make-money-heres-how-he-does-it/|publisher=Venture Beat|date=August 23, 2012}}</ref> Patel describes KISSmetrics as Crazy Egg 2.0--the service shows who visited, their actions, and how companies can use that information to improve sales and customer experience by tracking the lifelong value of the customer.<ref name=forbes/><ref name=kisssm>{{cite web|last=Kincaid|first=Jason|title=KISSmetrics Helps You Hone In On Stats That Actually Matter With Cohort Reports|url=http://techcrunch.com/2011/09/23/kissmetrics-helps-you-hone-in-on-stats-that-actually-matter-with-cohort-reports/|publisher=TechCrunch|date=September 23, 2011}}</ref>
The company closed a $1 million [[seed round]] led by True Ventures in 2008. In mid-2009 it closed a $3 million round led by [[Polaris Ventures]], and has also secured angel investments from [[Dave McClure]], [[Bobby Yazdani]], and [[Nils Johnson]].<ref name=tcfund>{{cite web|last=Kincaid|first=Jason|title=KISSmetrics: A Conversion Funnel Tool That Gives Your Site A Memory|url=http://techcrunch.com/2010/07/22/kissmetrics-conversion-funnel/|publisher=TechCrunch|date=July 22, 2010}}</ref> Patel's advisors at KissMetrics include [[Eric Ries]], [[Sean Ellis]], Jeff Veen, Jeff Hammerbacher, and Ed Baker.<ref name=tcfund/>
Since its launch in May 2008, the company has signed on more than 1,900 paying customers and has tracked more than 4.5 billion people and their 36 billion interactions.<ref name=forbes/>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.quicksprout.com/ Neil Patel's Blog--QuickSprout]
